<target_code>
Here is the code of completed_callback:

```c
static void
completed_callback (void *cls,
                    struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    void **req_cls,
                    enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct timeval *tv = *req_cls;
  struct timeval tve;
  uint64_t delta;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == tv)
    return;
  gettimeofday (&tve, NULL);

  delta = ((uint64_t) (tve.tv_sec - tv->tv_sec)) * 1000000LL
          + (uint64_t) tve.tv_usec - (uint64_t) tv->tv_usec;
  if (delta < SMALL)
    small_deltas[delta]++;
  else
    fprintf (stdout, "D: %" PRIu64 " 1\n", delta);
  free (tv);
}
```

explanation: MISRA C Rule 17.2 concerns direct or indirect calls that could result in recursion. The only statements in this function that perform external function calls are the three fragments listed above; these should be investigated to determine whether those called functions (or functions they call) could call back into completed_callback. All other lines in the function do not perform function calls and therefore cannot create an indirect recursive call chain: the declarations, the (void) unused-parameter casts, the NULL check and return, the time-delta arithmetic, the array increment small_deltas[delta]++, and the if/else control structure are not function calls and thus need not be investigated for Rule 17.2. Note also that any registration or invocation of completed_callback (e.g. in the library that calls this callback) is outside the shown snippet and should be examined separately if relevant.
